messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:24): hdh: Oh, nice, that sounds like what I was looking for
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:25): I guess I didn't see it because it didn't exist when I looked :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:25): although it looks like it doesn't yet exist in a downloadable form :-(
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:27): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: what exactly do you need?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:30): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: Something to render the in-game GUI of a 3D OpenGL RTS game
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:31): (and to handle scripted interaction, respond to user input, etc)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): (and to work on Windows/Linux/OSX, and to be open source but not GPL, etc)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): (Also the scripting has to be JavaScript, to be consistent with the rest of the game's scripts)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:33): (I don't need to base it on HTML, but it'd seem kind of nice if I could)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:34): for some reason I thought you worked on Opera
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:34): Alp's thing does sound like what you want
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:35): All I do with Opera is use it and find bugs in it :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:36): and then usually complain about the bugs, because I've got nothing better to complain about
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (01:37): Much appreciated. (c;
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:38): sorry wrong channel
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (01:51): http://www.patentlyo.com/patent/2008/07/the-death-of-go.html
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:53): we can only hope
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:54): Hmm, the URL made me think someone had patented Go and was going to prevent anyone from playing it
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (01:55): woah, the PTO is proposing making software patents unpatentable?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:56): the PTO is still saying that software is patentable, but this person is saying recent PTO rules are incompatible with that
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:56): note that the blogger there is a very pro-software-patents person

57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (01:57): "the PTO Board of Patent Appeals and Interferences has now supplied an answer to that question: A general purpose computer is not a particular machine, and thus innovative software processes are unpatentable if they are tied only to a general purpose computer."
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:57): it's written not to make nerds happy but to make patent attourneys unhappy
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (01:57): it's made nerds happy, though

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:58): my brother says that his analysis is reasonable but that nothing will change in practice until courts have to rule on the issues, and that will override the PTO's decisions anyway
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:58): (my brother is a patent attourney)
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (01:58): well, I am against software patents on the basis that mathematical algorithms should not be patented and software is essentially a mathematical algorithm
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (02:01): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: why shouldn't mathematical algorithms be patented?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:01): besides, mathematical algorithms are expressly unpatentable under US patent law
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (02:02): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: dunno, a lot of things are patented and i don't know why they should be

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): software patents would be ok if it wasn't for two things, one, their insane lifetime in an industry that moves as fast as IT, and two, patent troll companies that aren't actually using the patents, just preventing other people from using them
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:03): well, the basic idea IMHO is that software is better protected by copyright

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): i'd feel much better about patents if the people suing were actually using patents for what they're intended, making money on the basis of a temporary monopoly

57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:04): if I had to write patent law over again, I would include a stipulation that if the company actually isn't provably acting on its patent, its patent becomes invalid
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:04): right

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:05): patents shouldn't be licensable either, inventing something and then making money by making other people pay you if they come up with the same idea is just not the point of the invention
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:05): but even the patentability of sofware is questionable, IMO
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I disagree about the licensability

57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:06): if I come up with a process to (hypothetically speaking, of course) turn water into oil, but I don't have the resources to actually make the machine that does that
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:07): I should be able to ask other companies if they would like to use the technology themselves for a fee
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): if you came up with a process to turn water into oil, finding vc funding would be the LAST of your problems
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): you'd be turning DOWN vc funding
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:07): bad example then
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:07): but you get the gist
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): if you came up with an algorithm to compress moving pictures slightly better

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:07): there's another thing, which is that in software we've got this great possibility for people can create products and give them away for zero marginal cost, and patents can destroy that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:08): should you be able to hold the entire industry hostage when others independently come up with the same idea?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:08): well, compressing movie pictures shouldn't be patentable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:08): anyway
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:08): since you're essentially taking one number and making it another number
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:08): patents suck, kthxbai
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:09): Stephen Wolfram would argue that everything that happens in the universe boils down to that too
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (02:09): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: did you change anything to the live forums.whatwg.org?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: upgraded to 3.0 and added the text confirmation thing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:09): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: More dangerously, so would I :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:09): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: did i break something?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:10): (dangerously insofar as that I'm hre)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:10): *here
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:10): well, there's one potential ramification if everything flies
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:11): no one can have any qualms about MP3 being patent-protected :-)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:11): it would solve a ton of problems
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:11): it would greatly simplify the issue of choosing standard codecs for <video> and <audio>
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:12): brings the thread back on topic
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (02:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: doesn't look like 3.0 and the admin panel says it's 2.0.22 like before
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:12): but I'm not holding my breath, to be honest. too good to be true
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: Yeah, that's certainly 2.0: even 3.0's subSilver looks different
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:12): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: all we have to do is hope that the justices are sufficiently computer-literate to understand why software patents are bad

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (02:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: got a PM from BearState saying that he got promted for his password when posting, so it looks like someone has messed up our phpbb
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:13): that's actually the best hope --- the current US Supreme Court is very skeptical about patents
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:14): putting Roberts in charge is the best thing the Bush administration ever did
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:14): which isn't saying much
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:14): well, my day is made if
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:14): a) Supreme Court goes back to the Betamax decision
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:14): b) Diamond v. Diehr is overturned
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (02:17): sorry, not necessarily Diehr's decision, but the State Street decision
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (02:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i think i'll edit the permissions so people can't post at all for now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): odd that it would not be 3.0
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:41): sees http://openwebfoundation.org/
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (02:43): that page's copyright is apparently owned by the year 2008
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (02:45): i like that. i think i'm going to assign my next copyright to whitespace (not any particular whitespace, but the general concept of whitespace).
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:45): The W in their logo font is a bit ugly
150ca666565bfcb850b2e2ee3c0f0c64 (02:46): I like it
